title-group.article-title: Mathematical modeling for seismic response of steel bridges with internal damping systems

article-meta.aff: National Technical University of Athens, Greece

author-notes.corresp: George T Michaltsos, National Technical University of Athens, 9 Iroon Polytechniou Street, Athens 157 80, Greece Email: michalts@central.ntua.gr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The present work deals with internal damping systems aiming to reduce the torsional and torsional-flexural modal amplitudes in steel bridges with open or closed cross sections. The effect of internal damping systems on the vibration modes and modal amplitudes is studied using simple models of bridges subjected to earthquake actions and useful results are gathered that can be used for design purposes.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The growth of materials technology, production methods and construction, as well as the exceptional improvement of computer-aided design methods, have led to light-weighted, more flexible and architectural bolder structures. At the same time, however, the requirements for safety, comfort and functionality of structures have also increased. This fact has intensified the efforts of designers to control structural vibrations caused mainly by dynamic loading, whether fatal or not, as noted by Bolt (1996). These efforts have led to the growth of the so-called vibration control systems for structures. The control of vibrations is achieved on a structure with an appropriate combination of mass and stiffness that basically influences its dynamic characteristics (Michaltsos and Raftoyiannis (2011)). Recently, however, it has been rendered popular to achieve vibration control of structures via the improvement of their ability to absorb their dynamic energy through damping systems. Damping systems can be placed externally or internally on a structure. In the first case (external insulation type), the most popular examples are the seismic insulation systems that are placed at the foundation of the structure, while in the second case (internal noninsulation type), the most representative examples are the energy absorption systems (energy dissipation devices). Design Codes, such as the Greek Aseismic Code EAK (2000) and the Eurocode 8 – Part 2 (ENV 1998-2, 2002), set the basic requirements for seismic analysis of bridges, where it is suggested either to use design spectra or to perform a series of time-history analyses, employing accelerograms from a sufficient number of characteristic earthquakes grown within the Greek territory, which can be obtained from the Institute of Engineering Seismology and Earthquake Engineering (ITSAK) or from Papazachos and Papazachou (1997). Many researchers, such as Price and Eberhard (1998), Chopra and Chintanapakdee (2001), Manfredi et al. (2003), Mavroeidis et al. (2004), Pavlou and Constantinou (2004) and Spyrakos et al. (2005), have also focused on the influence of near-fault and long-distance earthquakes on the dynamic response of various simple structural systems. In the present work, internal energy absorption systems are examined aiming to restrict torsional and torsional-flexural oscillations of steel bridges that, due to their cross-sectional shape, have relatively small torsional stiffness. By employing simple mathematical models, the effect of internal damping systems on the vibration eigenmodes and the dynamic response of bridges under earthquake actions are studied and useful conclusions on the design of structures with similar damping systems are obtained.

sec.title: 2. Mathematical model
sec.p:
Without restriction of the generality, let us consider a simply supported bridge with length ℓ, to which a system of internal dampers, as shown in Figure 1, has been attached at point Α with x = xF. This damping system is constituted by masses M1 and M2, each one placed at distance e from the gravity center of the cross section, which can oscillate only in the vertical direction, and by mass M3, which is placed at the center of gravity and can oscillate only in the horizontal direction. It is obvious that the system of masses M1 and M2 modifies via the springs with constants k1, k2 and the damping coefficients c1, c2 both the vertical and the torsional oscillations of the bridge, while mass M3 modifies the horizontal oscillation via the spring with constant k3 and damping coefficient c3. The bridge has a uniformly distributed mass m and is subjected to movement of the supports due to earthquake. The response of the structure can be described from the vertical displacement w(x,t), the horizontal displacement v(x,t) and the rotation θ(x,t) of the cross section. Figure 1.
Bridge model with internal dampers and deformed configuration.

Thus, the equations of motion of the bridge are as follows: (1)EIyw″″+cyw·+mw··+M1w··F1+M2w··F2=fz(t)δ(x-xF)-mw··sEIzv″″-EIzzMθ″″+czv·+mv··+M3v··F=fy(t)δ(x-xF)-mv··sECwθ″″-EIzzMv″+cθθ·-GJθ″+Θxθ··+e(M1w··F1-M2w··F2)=mx(t)δ(x-xF)(1) where Ε and G are the elasticity and shear modulus, respectively, Ιy and Ιz are the moments of inertia of the cross section about axes y and z, respectively, J and Cw are the torsion and distortion constants, respectively, cy, cz, cθ are the structural damping coefficients, zM is the distance between the shear center M and the gravity center S, and Θx is the rotary inertia of the cross section about the longitudinal x-axis. The functions fz(t), fy(t) and mx(t) on the right-hand side of the equations of motion are time functions under determination and they correspond to forces and moment from the internal damping system at position xF in the system, expressed via the Dirac-δ function, while vs and ws are the horizontal and vertical displacements due to ground motion, respectively.

From dynamic equilibrium of masses Μ1 and Μ2: (2)M1z··1+c1(z·1-w·F1)+k1(z1-wF1)=-M1w··s (3)M2z··2+c2(z·2-w·F2)+k2(z2-wF2)=-M2w··s and similarly for mass Μ3: (4)M3z··3+c3(z·3-v·F)+k3(z3-vF)=-M3v··s where wF=w(xF,t), vF=v(xF,t), θF=θ(xF,t) and (5)wF1=wF+eθFwF2=wF-eθF

Introducing Equation (5) into Equations (2) and (3), the total vertical force that acts onto the beam due to the masses of the dampers is obtained: (6)fz(t)=M1(g-z··1-w··s)+M2(g-z··2-w··s)+M3(g-w··F-w··s)==F1+c1(z·1-w·F-eθ·F)++k1(z1-wF-eθF)+F2++c2(z·2-w·F+eθ·F)+k2(z2-wF+eθF)++F3-M3(w··F+w··s)
The total horizontal force that acts onto the beam due to the masses of the dampers is (7)fy(t)=-(M1+M2)(v··F+v··s)-M3(z··3+v··s)=-(M1+M2)v··F++c3(z·3-v·F)+k3(z3-vF)-(M1+M2)v··s(7)
Finally, the total moment that acts onto the beam is (8)mx(t)=e[F1+c1(z·1-w·F-eθ·F)+k1(z1-wF-eθF)]--e[F2+c2(z·2-w·F+eθ·F)+k2(z2-wF+eθF)]

The weight of the dampers’ mass is taken into account in expressions (6) and (8) through the terms F1 = Μ1g, F2 = Μ2g and F3 = Μ3g, while the analysis results include both the seismic actions and the gravity forces. Moreover, masses Μ1, Μ2 and Μ3 are assumed to be at the same level as the gravity center of the cross section. In common practice, the vertical dampers have the same characteristics; therefore, one may set Μ1 = Μ2, c1 = c2 and k1 = k2. Nevertheless, it is observed that the first of Equations (1) is not coupled with the other two, while in contrast, the second and third of Equations (1) are coupled due to the presence of the term zM and, hence, they will have a common time function. Based on the above, a solution of the problem in the form of separate variables is possible where the dynamic displacements w(x,t), v(x,t) and θ(x,t) are written in the following form: (9)w(x,t)=∑nWn(x)Tzn(t)v(x,t)=∑nVn(x)Tθn(t)θ(x,t)=∑nΦn(x)Tθn(t)
Functions Wn, Vn and Φn in Equation (9) are the shape functions corresponding to the nth eigenmode and Tzn, Tθn are the corresponding time functions under determination.

For the vertical vibration of a simply supported beam in free motion, the shape functions Wn are determined from the boundary conditions Wn(0)=0, W″n(0)=0, Wn(ℓ)=0, W″n(ℓ)=0, and are (10)Wn(x)=sinnπxℓ with corresponding eigenfrequencies given by (11)ωzn2=n4π4EIymℓ4

Introducing the first of Equations (9) into the first of Equations (1) and including the mass terms of Μ1 and Μ2 into the term fz(t), one obtains (12)EIy∑nWn″″Tzn+cy∑nWnT·zn+m∑nWnT··zn=fZ*(t)δ(x-xF)-mw··s
Given that the shape function Wn satisfies the equation for free motion EIyWn″″-mωzn2Wn=0, one may write (13)m∑nωzn2WnTzn+cy∑nWnT·zn+m∑nWnT··zn=fz*(t)δ(x-xF)-mw··s

Multiplying the above equation by Wn and integrating along the length of the beam, the following differential equation for the time function Τzn is obtained: (14)T··zn+cymT·zn+ωzn2Tzn=1m∫0ℓWn2dx[2F1+c1(z·1+z·2-2∑nWFnT·zn)++k1(z1+z2-2∑nWFnTzn)+F3-M3∑nWFnT··zn]WFn-m∫0ℓWndxm∫0ℓWn2dxw··s where WFn=Wn(xF).

Similarly, the shape functions Vn and Φn for the torsional-flexural vibration of the beam in free motion result from solution of the differential equation: (15)αΦn(8)+βΦn(6)+γΦn(4)+δΦn(2)+ɛΦn=0 where α=-ECwEIz, β=EIzGJ, γ=ECwmωθn2+EIzΘxωθn2, δ=-GJmωθn2, ɛ=-Θxmωθn4, while it is (16)Vn=1mzMωθn 2(ECwΦn″″-GJΦ″n-Θxωθn 2Φn)

The characteristic equation of Equation (15) is an algebraic one with eight roots ρ and, hence, its general integral is given by the expression (17)Φ=∑icieρix+∑jcjeρjx where ± ρi are the real roots and ± ρj are the conjugated complex roots of the characteristic of Equation (15). Introducing Equation (17) into Equation (16) and employing the boundary conditions Vn(0)=V″n(0)=Vn(ℓ)=V″n(ℓ)=0 and Φn(0)=Φ″n(0)=Φn(ℓ)=Φ″n(ℓ)=0 for the simply supported beam, one arrives at a homogeneous system of equations with eight unknowns (i.e. the constants ci and cj). By setting the determinant of the coefficients of the unknowns equal to zero, the eigenfrequencies ωθn and the corresponding shape functions Vn and Φn are obtained from Equations (17) and (16).

Introducing the second and the third of Equations (9) into the corresponding of Equations (1) results in (18)EIz∑nV″″nTθn-EIzzM∑nΦ″″nTθn+cz∑nVnT·θn+m∑nVnT··θn=fy*(t)δ(x-xF)-mv··sECw∑nΦ″″nTθn-EIzzM∑nV″nTθn+cθ∑nΦnT·θn-GJ∑nΦ″nTθn+Θx∑nΦnT··θn=mx*(t)δ(x-xF) and given that Vn and Φn satisfy the relations EIzV″″n-EIzzMΦ″″n-mωθn2Vn=0 and ECwΦ″″n-EIzzMV″″n-GJΦ″n-Θxωθn2Φn=0, one may write (19)m∑nωθn2VnTθn+cz∑nVnT·θn+m∑nVnT··θn=fy*(t)δ(x-xF)-mv··sΘx∑nωθn2ΦnTθn+cθ∑nΦnT·θn+Θx∑nΦnT··θn=mx*(t)δ(x-xF)

Multiplying the first of Equations (19) by Vn and integrating along the length of the beam, and the second of Equations (19) by Φn and also integrating along the length of the beam, it follows that (20)∑n(∫0ℓmVn2dx)·(ωθn2Tθn+czmT·θn+T··θn)=∫0ℓ[fy*(t)δ(x-xF)-mv··s]Vndx∑n(∫0ℓΘxΦn2dx)·(ωθn2Tθn+czmT·θn+T··θn)=∫0ℓ[mx*(t)δ(x-xF)]Φndx

Using the relations in expressions (9), Equations (2)–(4) are written as follows: (22)M1z··1+c1(z·1-∑nWFnT·zn-e∑nΦFnT·θn)+k1(z1-∑nWFnTzn-e∑nΦFnTθn)=-M1w··s (23)M2z··2+c2(z·2-∑nWFnT·zn+e∑nΦFnT·θn)+k2(z2-∑nWFnTzn+e∑nΦFnTθn)=-M2w··s (24)M3z··3+c3(z·3-∑nVFnT·θn)+k3(z3-∑nVFnTθn)=-M3v··s

Equations (14), along with Equations (21)–(24), form a system with unknowns, the time functions z1(t), z2(t), z3(t), Tzn(t) and Τθn(t), which can be solved only numerically via numerical integration. This is performed by means of the high accuracy Dormand–Prince 8 integration scheme (eighth-order Runge–Kutta-based method for nonstiff problems with initial step size T/100 – T being the corresponding eigenperiod – and automatic step size control) for any motion type. The dynamic responses, along with the corresponding plots, are given in numerical examples. It should be noted at this stage that the number of equations in (14) and (21) depends on the number n of the considered eigenshapes.

sec.title: 3. Numerical results
sec.p:
Let us consider a simply supported bridge with length ℓ = 30 m. Two cases of cross-sectional geometry – closed and open – will be studied, as shown in Figure 2. Both sections are made from structural steel with modulus of elasticity Ε = 2.1 × 108 kPa, shear modulus G = 8.077 × 107 kPa and specific weight γS = 78.5 kN/m3. Figure 2.
Closed and open cross-section geometry of a steel bridge.

The closed section has the following characteristics: Α = 0.18743 m2, Iy = 0.08644 m4, Iz = 0.2018 m4, J = 0. 1316 m4, Cw = 0.001142 m6, m = 1500 kg/m, Θx = 2306 kg·m2/m and zM = 0.1763 m. The first three eigenfrequencies for vertical vibration are ωz1 = 38.15 sec−1, ωz2 = 152.60 sec−1 and ωz3 = 343.36 sec−1, with corresponding shape functions W1(x) = sin(πx/ℓ), W2(x) =sin(2πx/ℓ) and W3(x) = sin(3πx/ℓ). For the torsional-flexural vibration of the bridge, and following the procedure described previously, the first three eigenfrequencies are obtained, which are ωθ1 = 58.29 sec−1, ωθ2 = 233.17 sec−1 and ωθ3 = 524.63 sec−1. The corresponding shape functions Φ1(x), V1(x), Φ2(x), V2(x) and Φ3(x), V3(x) are subsequently determined from Equations (17) and (16).

The open section has the following characteristics: Α = 0.165 m2, Iy = 0.07048 m4, Iz = 0.2988 m4, J = 3.538 ×10−5 m4, Cw = 0.1331m6, m = 1320 kg/m, Θx = 2955 kg·m2/m and zM = −1.270 m. The first three eigenfrequencies for vertical vibration are ωz1 = 36.72 sec−1, ωz2 = 146.867 sec−1 and ωz3 = 330.45 sec−1, while for torsional-flexural vibration of the bridge the first three eigenfrequencies are ωθ1 = 75.60 sec−1, ωθ2 = 302.39 sec−1 and ωθ3 = 680.39 sec−1.

Two damping systems are placed in the bridge at the mid—length (xF = 0.5ℓ), which consist of the three dampers shown in Figure 1, that is, dampers 1 and 2 at a distance of 3.60 m between each other (e = 1.80 m) and damper 3 at the center of gravity of the cross section, in order to modify both the vertical (w) and the torsional-flexural (v,ϕ) vibration of the bridge. In this work we focus mostly on the torsional-flexural response of the bridge. We assume that the dampers have masses Μ1 = Μ2 = Μ and Μ3 = 2Μ and spring constants k1 = k2 = kp and k3 = 2 kp, while their damping coefficient is c1 = c2 = cp and c3 = 2cp. We study the case with high damping ratio ξp = 10% and the case without damping (ξp = 0). Regarding the mass and stiffness of the dampers, a case with very stiff dampers (kp = 10000 kN/m) and a second one with intermediate stiffness (kp = 2000 kN/m) corresponding to the fundamental frequency of the system ωθ1 are considered. Finally, a parametric study of the response of the bridge for damper/bridge mass ratios Μ/m = 0.01, 0.05 και 0.10 is conducted.

Two cases of seismic excitation are examined: a ‘near-fault’ earthquake that is characterized by a pulse, and a ‘long-distance’ earthquake that is similar to a classic harmonic excitation. For this reason, the accelerograms of two representative earthquakes from the Greek territory have been chosen, namely the Leukas earthquake (2003) that falls into the first category and the Corinth earthquake (1981) that falls into the second category.

In Figure 3 one can see the horizontal and torsional seismic response at the mid-length (xF = 0.5ℓ) of a bridge with a closed cross section under the Corinth earthquake with dampers having mass Μ = 0.5 t and intermediate stiffness kp = 2000 kN/m without damping (cp = 0). Correspondingly, in Figure 4 one can see the seismic response of the same bridge and dampers but with damping ratio ξp = 10%. In these figures, Ω is the eigenfrequency of the dampers and ω is the fundamental frequency of the bridge in lateral-flexural vibration. From a comparison between the two responses, one can observe that the presence of damping cp reduces slightly the response amplitude in the initial stage, while this reduction is drastically increased with time. Figure 3.
Horizontal and torsional response of the bridge with a closed cross section for the Corinth earthquake and intermediate dampers with Μ/m = 0.05, Ω/ω = 1.0 and ξp = 0%.
Figure 4.
Horizontal and torsional response of the bridge with a closed cross section for the Corinth earthquake and intermediate dampers with Μ/m = 0.05, Ω/ω = 1.0 and ξp = 10%.

In Figures 5 and 6 one can see the horizontal and torsional seismic response of the bridge with an open cross section at the mid-length (xF = 0.5ℓ) for the Corinth earthquake with dampers having mass Μ = 0.5 t and high stiffness kp = 10000 kN/m and without damping or with damping ratio ξp = 10%. One can observe that the internal damping cp does not influence the response amplitude, while the reduced torsional stiffness GJ in conjunction with the high eccentricity zM between the gravity center S and the shear center M results in an increase of the maximum amplitude. Figure 5.
Horizontal and torsional response of the bridge with an open cross section for the Corinth earthquake and stiff dampers with Μ/m = 0.05, Ω/ω = 1.0 and ξp = 0%.
Figure 6.
Horizontal and torsional response of the bridge with an open cross section for the Corinth earthquake and stiff dampers with Μ/m = 0.05, Ω/ω = 1.0 and ξp = 10%.

In Figures 7 and 8 one can see the horizontal and torsional seismic response of the bridge with an open cross section for the Leukas earthquake with dampers having intermediate and high stiffness and no damping (cp = 0). It is observed that increasing the stiffness of the dampers leads to a drastic reduction (up to 40%) of the maximum response amplitude in contrast to the same case regarding the Corinth earthquake. Figure 7.
Horizontal and torsional response of the bridge with an open cross section for the Leukas earthquake and intermediate dampers with Μ/m = 0.05, Ω/ω = 1.0 and ξp = 0%.
Figure 8.
Horizontal and torsional response of the bridge with an open cross section for the Leukas earthquake and stiff dampers with Μ/m = 0.05, Ω/ω = 1.0 and ξp = 0%.

Next, a parametric study regarding the response of the bridge for various ratios of the damper mass to bridge mass Μ/m = 0.01, 0.05 and 0.10 and various damper stiffness values kp expressed through the ratio Ω/ω is conducted.

In Figure 9 one can see the maximum amplitude ratio of the response of the bridge with dampers to the response of the same bridge without dampers δ/δο for the Leukas earthquake. It can be observed that for internal systems (oscillators) without damping, as the mass ratio Μ/m increases and as the eigenfrequency of the dampers Ω approaches the fundamental frequency ω of the system, there is a significant reduction of the maximum response amplitude ratio δ/δο up to 40%. Similar behavior is observed also for internal systems with damping ratio ξp = 10%, whereas the additional reduction of the maximum response amplitude ratio δ/δο is practically small (∼5%). Thus, the reduction of the maximum response amplitude is achieved by the dampers mainly through a complex response of the system and not by using additional internal damping devices in the oscillators. Figure 9.
Maximum response ratios δ/δο versus frequency ratio Ω/ω for various values of mass ratio Μ/m (a) without damping (cp = 0) and (b) with damping ratio ξp = 10%.

sec.title: 4. Conclusions
sec.p:
Based on the analytical model and the results presented herein, the following conclusions can be drawn.
In long-distance earthquakes, such as the Corinth earthquake, the damping of oscillators reduces slightly the response amplitude in the initial phase of the earthquake, while it leads to a significant reduction with time.
In bridges with an open cross section and small torsional stiffness that is characterized by large torsional-flexural vibration amplitudes, the damping of oscillators has almost no influence on the maximum response amplitude.
In near-fault earthquakes, such as the Leukas earthquake, the increase of oscillator stiffness decreases drastically the maximum response amplitude (up to 40%), in contrast to the corresponding case of long-distance earthquakes, where the corresponding reduction is considerably smaller.
As the mass of oscillators increases and their eigenfrequency approaches the fundamental frequency of the system, a significant reduction of the maximum response amplitude of up to 40% is observed. A reduction of the maximum response amplitude when using internal damping systems is achieved mainly via a complex response of the system and not by using additional internal damping devices in the oscillators.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.

MichaltsosTGRaftoyiannisIG (2011) Bridges Dynamics, Sharjah: Bentham Publ.

PriceTEEberhardMO (1998) Effects of spatially varying ground motions on short bridges. ASCE Journal of Structural Engineering, 124(8): 948–955.
SpyrakosCCManiatakisChATaflambasJ (2005) Critical evaluation of near-source seismic records in Greece. In: Proceedings of ERES’05, Greece: Skiathos, pp. 53–62.
